afd.explanation: AFD supports the use of video surveillance in public transport to combat crime and ensure safety.

citations.content: AFD: Companies and government institutions use these technical possibilities to research the lives of citizens and consumers down to the last detail.

AFD: This allows detailed usage and movement profiles to be created. Even the knowledge of the recording and merging of such data influences the behavior of citizens. We demand the restriction of location and device monitoring to the minimum necessary level, as well as the mandatory possibility of switching off by the user. Furthermore, we demand complete transparency with regard to the monitoring possibilities for the user. We are expressly committed to the abolition of the mandatory speed warning system (Intelligent Speed Assistance), as it patronizes the driver. Fight against disinformation Critical and supposedly disturbing opinions, as long as they do not cross the line into criminal liability, are part of the constitutionally guaranteed right of every citizen of our country. The expression of free opinion in the media of any kind also represents a possibility for the citizen to control the state. Freedom of expression also includes the right to make mistakes. Recently, however, attempts have been made by public and "non-state" actors to restrict freedom of expression by directly banning or delegitimizing critical opinions. More and more public and non-state actors, so-called "NGOs", such as "Faktenchecker" or "Correctiv", are being used for disinformation campaigns through state commissioning and financing. As an example, the campaigns for the Corona vaccination should be remembered here.

cdu.explanation: CDU supports the use of video surveillance in public transport to better protect women, the elderly, children, people with disabilities and other particularly vulnerable groups.

citations.content: CDU: We are tightening criminal law in order to better protect women, the elderly, children, people with disabilities and other particularly vulnerable groups. We are increasing the maximum penalty for stalking. We will punish bodily injuries, especially if they are committed with a knife, and group rape much more severely. We do not leave the victims of domestic violence, especially women and children, alone. Your protection is a priority for us. We are therefore developing a security concept and strengthening the women's shelters. We are increasingly using electronic ankle bracelets so that perpetrators of violence against women keep their distance from their former partners. We ensure that where children are cared for, there are binding and standardised protection concepts across the board. In terms of access rights, the following should apply: If a parent inflicts violence on the child, the child must be excluded from care. There is still exploitation, violence and abuse. Human trafficking, forced prostitution and clan crime are a great evil and must be fought.

CDU: The protection of the population and the security interests of our state must take precedence over the data protection interests of the individual. No one who violates our laws should be given false protection by the anonymity of the Internet. In the fight against serious crimes, such as sexual violence against children, or to prevent terrorist attacks, we oblige Internet service providers to store IP addresses and port numbers for a minimum period of time. We give our security authorities the widest possible authority to use electronic facial recognition and allow them to use modern software to analyse large amounts of data, police databases and social networks. We are creating digital powers such as source telecommunications surveillance, online searches and automatic data analysis using AI for all federal security agencies. We are expanding the possibility of monitoring telecommunications and evaluating radio cells. This is especially true for crimes such as burglary and grandchild tricks, which cut deeply into the victims' sense of security. We need better staffing of our courts, competitive salaries, a boost in digitalisation and faster court proceedings.

CDU: We need better staffing of our courts, competitive salaries, a boost in digitalisation and faster court proceedings. The punishment must follow the deed on the heels. Relieving staff is mainly possible with the help of technical processes and the support of AI. Appreciation for security authorities and emergency services We stand firmly by the side of our security authorities, customs and our emergency services in the police, fire brigade, technical relief agency, aid organisations, rescue services and the Bundeswehr. They deserve support, support and appreciation. Attacks on those who protect us will be punished more harshly. We also include health professionals in this protection. Police officers must be well equipped so that they can protect us and themselves well. We ensure this, for example by equipping the entire area with distance electric impulse devices (TA-SER) and the use of bodycams – even for operations in living spaces. Where there are allegations against them, they must be clarified by public prosecutors and courts. We are abolishing special investigators, such as the federal police commissioner set up by the traffic light. We reject the introduction of mandatory identification for federal police officers.

CDU: Zero-tolerance strategy We have a zero-tolerance strategy in the fight against crime. Anyone who does not comply with the law must be punished immediately. Everyone must be able to move freely in everyday life, on the way to work and in their free time without fear. We oppose the neglect of public space, because it is often the starting point for crime.

CDU: It is important to have local public transport that is needs-based and future-proof. This also includes a reliable and robust infrastructure as well as an attractive range of urban and rural services. We want to create new transparency in the financing of public transport and ensure adequate financing. To this end, we are streamlining the company and repositioning it. For more competition, the infrastructure and transport sectors must be separated more closely than before. The federal government provides the main financing for maintenance, expansion and modernisation. We are paying particular attention to the expansion of cross-border infrastructure, for example in the direction of Poland. We are reducing the excessive burden of CO2 pricing and CO2 surcharges in the transport industry. We ensure lasting financial stability that is independent of fluctuating budgetary resources. In addition, we need to mobilize more capital in the short term to solve the investment backlog. To this end, we rely on strong incentives for private investors.

spd.explanation: SPD does not explicitly mention video surveillance in public transport but supports the creation of a modern Federal Police Act that gives the Federal Police clear powers to effectively meet today's security policy challenges.

citations.content: SPD: This will make local public transport affordable for the breadth of society. Together with the states and municipalities, we will strengthen the financing of local public transport in the long term. The federal government's regionalisation funds are important for this. We will legally stipulate the mandatory takeover of staff for all employees in the event of a change of operator in local and regional transport. We will also enforce the obligation to comply with collective bargaining agreements in procurement procedures. In metropolitan areas, public transport is to be given priority wherever possible. Even those who cannot or do not want to drive a car must be able to be mobile. This requires good accessibility and good bus and train frequencies, both in the countryside and in the city. More for you. Better for Germany.

SPD: We are creating a modern Federal Police Act that gives the Federal Police clear powers to effectively meet today's security policy challenges. We want police officers to receive respect and recognition for their indispensable services to our society. Attacks on them, as well as on rescue workers and helpers, must be consistently punished and punished more severely. In addition, we want to quickly increase the protection of emergency services through improved technical equipment, training and a superior force approach in threatening situations. We must stand by the people who risk their lives every day for our safety. In order to better ensure that no one is harmed when fireworks are set off, we are examining the expansion of the legal options for municipalities to be able to act in a more targeted manner on the ground. In addition, we will launch an initiative with the Länder to harmonise the federal differences in the area of police and assembly law. At the same time, the riot police of the states and the federal government are to be strengthened so that the fundamental right to assembly can be protected everywhere. We fight organized crime effectively and sustainably. To this end, we are modernising the definition of organised crime and strengthening our security authorities. We also want to focus on organized white-collar crime and take better account of network-like structures.

bsw.explanation: BSW agrees with the use of video surveillance in public transport, but emphasizes the importance of clear authorisation bases and boundaries for the use of such technologies.

citations.content: BSW: Safe streets and squares: For a well-equipped police force More and more people no longer feel safe in public spaces. We are committed to ensuring that the police are staffed and equipped in such a way that they can provide security from crime. Not least for the effective fight against clan crime, the police Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht - Reason and Justice Glinkastr.

BSW: This requires sufficient staff. It is an untenable state of affairs that in some cities the police can no longer really support victims of crime due to an acute shortage of personnel, and even serious crimes are no longer prosecuted. We want to change that. We oppose the privatization of security tasks. Security belongs in the professional hands of the police. Police officers, firefighters, rescue and disaster relief workers, doctors and health professionals as well as countless volunteers stand up for people's lives and rights every day. When it comes down to it, they must protect our lives. For this commitment and their passionate commitment, these everyday heroes need our support. Our police must be put in a position to put a stop to criminals, terrorists and extremists more effectively. We demand that the police be solidly equipped with modern resources and IT – especially with regard to current challenges such as cybercrime and terrorism. In doing so, we rely on excellent training and further education in academies and training centres.

BSW: It is important that all powers give the safety authorities exactly the tools they need to perform their tasks and must always have clear and unambiguous boundaries. Authorisation bases with a particularly high level of interference – such as the AI-based evaluation of inventory data or automated data comparison – are only necessary where our society needs to be protected from extreme, terrorist or other serious crimes. House searches for insulting politicians or scouring the Internet for possible insults are certainly not among the tasks that our police and investigative authorities should deal with. Politicians who employ entire public prosecutors' offices to prosecute their critics for harmless postings on social media are diverting capacities that are needed for more important things. While lèse-majesté against foreign heads of government has no longer been punishable since 2017, the Bundestag added the offence of insulting a "person standing in the political life of the people" to the Criminal Code in 2021. However, it is precisely politicians who occupy positions of power and whose decisions often have direct consequences for people's lives and prosperity that have to face criticism from citizens in a free democratic state governed by the rule of law.

BSW: Tracking by means of cookies or other methods should be avoided as a matter of principle and should not be requested via cookie banner if the user specifies this in the browser settings. This also applies to people who do not have a computer or an Internet connection. They must all be able to use the services of the railway and local transport at no extra charge and to receive their packages. They must be able to get appointments at offices, with doctors and doctors. The same goes for people who don't have access to the internet. Alliance Sahra Wagenknecht - Reason and Justice Glinkastr.

volt.explanation: Volt supports the use of video surveillance in public transport as part of their commitment to strengthening the protection of religious freedom and the security of religious institutions. They also support the digitization of case processing to improve law enforcement.

citations.content: Volt: We all benefit from efficient and transparent policing. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Integration of digital technologies: Technologies and equipment, such as bodycams, reporting systems and analytics tools, will be more integrated into the service. RESOLUTELY FIGHTING CYBERCRIME With an ever-evolving threat landscape, it is important to ensure the protection of personal data and the digital security of everyone. This ensures trust in digital rights and at the same time the competitiveness of Germany as a business location. Clearly defined government contact points and practicable data protection regulations enable companies to work securely, in compliance with the law and in an innovation-friendly manner. At the same time, access to innovation-relevant data is made possible without interfering with personal rights. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Expansion of cybercrime units: Cybercrime units of the police and judiciary will be strengthened.

Volt: For some time now, however, it has been part of the everyday life of the police and public prosecutor's office that the workload increases and overtime is accumulated to an unjustifiable extent. A reduction in overtime and a normalization of the workload are not in sight. This jeopardizes the quality of work and creates a risk both for the staff and for the people whose safety it is supposed to ensure. Law enforcement authorities and their staff must therefore be strengthened and supported in the best possible way in the fulfilment of their tasks. RETURN TO CORE POLICE TASKS Police are often overburdened with tasks outside their core area, which limits their ability to perform and endangers public safety. In addition, there is a shortage of staff in many places. A return to the core tasks and measures for recruiting personnel enables high-quality police work that increases the safety of the population. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Delegation of subsidiary tasks: Tasks such as dog tax controls or prison transports are returned to the responsible administrations. This includes measures to make training more attractive. SECURITY IN THE DIGITAL SPACE People's lives are increasingly taking place in the digital space.

Volt: Strengthened law enforcement protects the population from the effects of these crimes. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Increased personnel: Special units at the BKA, customs and in the federal states will be strengthened. ADAPTED LAW ENFORCEMENT Effective and efficient prosecution is essential to solve crimes quickly and fairly. We all benefit from accelerated case processing, better cooperation between authorities and a targeted use of resources. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Digitization of case processing: The entire process from the filing of the complaint to the public prosecutor's office will be digitized. NATIONWIDE STANDARDS FOR THE POLICE The challenges of modern crime require uniform and coordinated police work throughout Germany. We all benefit from more efficient law enforcement, the same standards and improved protection against crime in all regions of German land.

Volt: It is important to strengthen the protection of religious freedom and the security of religious institutions. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Protection of religious institutions: The protection and security of places of worship and places of worship will be expanded. SAFETY FOR PEOPLE WITH EXPERIENCE OF RACISM Discrimination and unfair treatment by security authorities undermine trust in public safety and justice. Targeted measures are needed to combat racist practices and empower those affected. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Independent complaints bodies: Independent complaints bodies will be expanded to take stronger action against discrimination.

Volt: STRENGTHENING FUNDAMENTAL DIGITAL RIGHTS We must preserve and strengthen digital fundamental rights, because they are of central importance for people's trust in the state. Clear legal framework conditions are needed to ensure the protection of privacy and prevent the misuse of surveillance technologies. This preserves the fundamental rights to privacy, informational self-determination and protection against arbitrary interference. That's why Volt is committed to this future: •  Rejection of surveillance technologies: There is no nationwide use and no automatic evaluation of surveillance technologies. Systems for biometric real-time remote identification (RBI) will be banned – even in sensitive places such as borders and prisons. The conditions and responsibilities for (temporary) exceptions, for example for the fight against terrorism, are clearly and transparently defined. A supervisory body based on the model of the UK Biometrics and Surveillance Camera Commissioner will be set up at the BfDI.

Volt: That is why Volt is committed to the following future: •  Uniform recording and transparency: A nationwide standardised reporting system will be introduced for the uniform recording of politically motivated crimes. A central pool of information documents extremist ideas and networks, which facilitates targeted prosecution. In addition, the penalties for hate crimes and support for extremist ideologies – especially in the digital space – will be tightened in order to create clear consequences for perpetrators.

linke.explanation: Linke is cautious about the use of video surveillance, emphasizing the importance of closing security gaps without exception and making the Federal Office for Information Security more independent.

citations.content: Linke: That is why we want to decriminalise IT security research, close security gaps without exception and make the Federal Office for Information Security more independent.

Linke: Every twentieth car trip could be avoided by the ticket - and it was only available for 3 months The increase in the subscription price to 58 euros is fatal and the different solutions in the states must be designed uniformly nationwide With a VAT exemption for local public transport, money will be freed up for local transport in the short term •  We want to reintroduce the 9-euro ticket immediately. For pupils, trainees, students and senior citizens, we want an immediate 0-euro ticket. The carriage of children as well as bicycles and dogs must be included For all subscribers, we demand six free rides per year in long-distance transport.

gruene.explanation: Gruene wants to make buses and trains places where passengers feel comfortable, including safety from assaults, especially against women. They do not explicitly mention video surveillance but focus on improving police action and attitude patterns.

citations.content: Gruene: In addition, we want to make buses and trains places where passengers feel comfortable. In addition to cleanliness, this also includes safety from assaults, especially against women.

Gruene: With the Federal Police Commissioner, we have created a contact point for police officers and citizens, whom we want to strengthen and develop. In this way, we are also improving the working conditions for police officers. As the executive organ of the state's monopoly on violence, the police also have a special responsibility. With a system for checks that sets out the reasons for checks, we want to make police action more transparent. In doing so, we want to design police control powers in such a way that they can be applied in a legally secure manner. In addition, we are introducing an anonymised labelling requirement for the Federal Police. In education and training, we want to raise awareness of diversity and develop a good error culture. Police action and attitude patterns have been comparatively little researched in Germany. That is why we want to open up the police more to scientific research. We want to focus more on dealing with exceptional psychological situations and improve psychosocial emergency care for emergency services and those affected. When the security authorities in Europe work together, they create more security for people in a Europe that is growing together. To this end, we are expanding the joint police centres in the border regions.

Gruene: We reconcile evidence-based domestic policy with civil rights and address the causes of crime. With investments, we also want to ensure that the police can work in modern properties and with good equipment, including digitally. Crime is increasingly shifting to the digital space – the police must be able to keep up with this technology. In order to prevent crime, we want to keep an eye on crime developments and make greater use of scientific expertise. We therefore want to enshrine the periodic safety report, which bundles this work, in law. Scientifically sound recording systems and databases enable precise situation pictures and assessments, promote good investigative work and lay the foundation for appropriate and legally secure police measures. We are therefore working towards improving police databases in the police information network. We are reforming police statistics to better record hate crime. Anyone who is known to the security authorities as an enemy of the constitution is not allowed to possess weapons. The number of legal and illegal firearms has increased in recent years. Too many acts of violence are still committed with firearms, especially in the domestic sphere. Every person who dies from a firearm is one too many.

fdp.explanation: FDP is critical of comprehensive surveillance in public spaces and rejects the use of automated facial recognition. They support video surveillance at individual crime hotspots but not as a replacement for police presence.

citations.content: FDP: Because we all have the right to move in public space without constant control. Video surveillance can make sense at individual crime hotspots such as train stations, but it never replaces the Presence of police officers and functioning prevention concepts. There must therefore be no comprehensive surveillance in public spaces. We reject the use of automated facial recognition in public spaces. The protection of privacy must also apply in the digital world. This includes a right to encryption so that private communication remains private. We reject network blocking, chat controls, upload filters, data retention and other forms of data collection without cause. With our Quick-freeze model, certain data can instead be secured by judicial order in the event of suspicion. German gun law must be designed with a sense of proportion. Sport shooters and hunters must not be unnecessarily burdened. Instead, the focus on endangerers and extremists should be strengthened by improved communication between the authorities and the fight against the illegal arms trade. We call for the development of a future-proof data infrastructure and the reform of the fragmented data protection supervisory authority in order to strengthen the innovative strength and competitiveness of the German economy.
